014package org.jdbi.v3.sqlobject.statement;
015
016import java.lang.annotation.ElementType;
017import java.lang.annotation.Retention;
018import java.lang.annotation.RetentionPolicy;
019import java.lang.annotation.Target;
020
021import org.jdbi.v3.sqlobject.SqlOperation;
022import org.jdbi.v3.sqlobject.statement.internal.SqlBatchHandler;
023
024/**
025 * Annotate a method to indicate that it will create and execute a SQL batch. At least one
026 * bound argument must be an Iterator or Iterable, values from this will be taken and applied
027 * to each row of the batch. Non iterable bound arguments will be treated as constant values and
028 * bound to each row.
029 * <p>
030 * Unfortunately, because of how batches work, statement customizers and sql statement customizers
031 * which affect SQL generation will *not* work with batches. This primarily effects statement location
032 * and rewriting, which will always use the values defined on the bound Handle.
033 * <p>
034 * If you want to chunk up the logical batch into a number of smaller batches (say around 1000 rows at
035 * a time in order to not wreck havoc on the transaction log, you should see
036 * {@link BatchChunkSize}
037 */
038@Retention(RetentionPolicy.RUNTIME)
039@Target({ElementType.METHOD})
040@SqlOperation(SqlBatchHandler.class)
041public @interface SqlBatch {
042    /**
043     * Returns the SQL string (or name) used for the batch.
044     *
045     * @return the SQL string (or name) used for the batch.
046     */
047    String value() default "";
048
049    /**
050     * Controls whether to execute the batch chunks in a transaction. Default is true.
051     *
052     * @return whether to execute the batch chunks in a transaction. Default is true (and it will be strange if you
053     * want otherwise).
054     */
055    boolean transactional() default true;
056}
